active_learning.discussion_prompt: Compare and contrast configuration drift in production environments versus pentest lab environments. How can tools like Ansible or Puppet prevent exploits commonly found in misconfigured systems (e.g., open ports or weak services)? Debate using examples from NIST SP 800-128 and CIS Control 5, considering real-world pentest scenarios.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in Penetration Testing Tools under the topic hierarchy: Cybersecurity > Penetration Testing And Ethical Hacking > Penetration Testing Tools > 001_Infrastructure and Environment Tools > Tool Management Systems > Configuration Management Tools. Incorporate these elements: - Learning Objectives: [INSERT FULL LIST FROM ABOVE] - Active Learning: [INSERT FULL DETAILS FROM ABOVE] - Scaffolding: [INSERT FULL 4 LAYERS FROM ABOVE] - Research Context: CM/SecCM (NIST SP 800-128), Baselines/CIs/IaC, CIS Controls (expand CIS 1,5), Tools (Ansible: agentless YAML; Puppet: DSL agents; Chef: Ruby; Terraform: provisioning; SaltStack: Python events) for pentest labs/Kali security. Generate 25 high-quality flashcards following this EXACT schema: For each card (numbered 1-25): **Front:** [Question]? A) [Distractor] B) [Distractor] C) [Correct] D) [Distractor] **Back:** **Correct Answer:** C) [Full text] **Explanation:** [1-2 sentences why correct, tie to objective/layer] **Detailed Rationale:** [Address misconceptions, reference NIST/CIS/tools] **Bloom's Level & Layer:** [e.g., APPLY - Layer 3] **Active Learning Link:** [e.g., 'Relates to problem-solving exercise'] Distractors: Strictly follow protocol - plausible, misconception-based. Cover all objectives/layers/tools evenly. Ensure university-level rigor, active recall, spaced repetition friendly. Voter consensus: Emphasize completeness on tools/CIS, pedagogy via Bloom's/scaffolding.
